channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Here’s What Happened on Day 73 of the War in Ukraine
item.description: Advances by Ukrainian forces in the northeast appeared to have forced Russians to move back toward the border, blowing up bridges behind them and contradicting the Kremlin narrative.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crater left by a Russian strike on Saturday in Malotaranivka, near Kramatorsk, in the Donbas region in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Eid Under the Taliban Shows a Changed Afghanistan
item.description: For many Afghans the holiday this past week served as a reminder of the dissonance between the promise of peace many had imagined and the realities of the end of the war.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary, Safiullah Padshah and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: John Lee Wins Hong Kong’s Rubber-Stamp Election
item.description: John Lee, who won a rubber-stamp leadership election on Sunday, will implement the next stage of China’s agenda for the former British colony.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Isaac Lawrence for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Lee waved to members of an election committee on Sunday after they chose him to be Hong Kong’s next chief executive.

item.title: Israel Captures 2 Palestinians Suspected in Deadly Ax Attack
item.description: The two men were caught hiding in a forest not far from where the killings were carried out, ending an intensive search. But the country remains on high alert.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Gil Cohen-Magen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Israeli security forces near Elad, Israel, on Sunday during a hunt for two Palestinians suspected of having killed three people in the town on Thursday.

item.title: Both Sides Harden Positions on Anniversary of Nazi Defeat in Europe
item.description: The war in Ukraine was marked by posturing and signaling, with each side ramping up its rhetoric as the battle ground on.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with the 93rd Brigade place camouflage netting on artillery captured from Russian forces near Sumy, in eastern Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: How Putin Has Hijacked Russia’s May 9 Holiday, Victory Day
item.description: Under President Vladimir V. Putin, Victory Day, marking the defeat of Nazi Germany, has come to celebrate modern Russian military might. The war in Ukraine is shifting its meaning further.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Maxim Shipenkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Armored vehicles taking part in a rehearsal in Red Square, Moscow, on Saturday in preparation for the Victory Day military parade.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Leader Declares State of Emergency Amid Protests
item.description: It was the second such declaration in weeks by Gotabaya Rajapaksa, whose government is being blamed for the country’s deepening economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The police dispersed protesters near Parliament in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Friday. Protesters say the political elite has failed a country trying to emerge from the shadow of civil war.

item.title: Russia’s Grave Miscalculation: Ukrainians Would Collaborate
item.description: Besides their military failures, the Russians entered the war believing they could persuade Ukrainians in the east to join their side. Those efforts have failed spectacularly.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Vilkul of Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine, in his office.

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Inaugurated for a 2nd Term as France President
item.description: “Rarely has our world and our country confronted such a combination of challenges,” Mr. Macron said, promising to govern France more inclusively.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Gonzalo Fuentes
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France reviewed troops on Saturday during his investiture ceremony in Paris.

item.title: North Korea Tests a Submarine-Launched Missile
item.description: Such missiles could extend the range of the North’s nuclear arsenal. The move came as the United States warned that the country might soon test a nuclear device.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Ahn Young-Joon/Associated Press
item.media:description: News coverage of North Korea’s missile program on a screen at a train station in Seoul on Saturday.

item.title: Head of U.N. Agency Resigns After Questions Arise About Loans
item.description: The little-known organization gave out $61 million in loans and grant money to a single British family, in a scandal that has shaken and embarrassed the U.N.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and David A. Fahrenthold
item.category: United Nations Office for Project Services
item.media:credit: Diego Simón Sánchez/EELG (GDA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Grete Faremo, the former executive director of the United Nations Office for Project Services, in 2019.

item.title: 3 Americans Die in Mysterious Circumstances at Bahamas Resort
item.description: It was unclear what happened but officials said they did not suspect foul play and there were no signs of trauma. Another guest was hospitalized in stable condition.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:credit: Dimitrios Kambouris/Getty Images for Sandals
item.media:description: Officials said that the cause of death of three Americans at the Sandals Emerald Bay resort in the Bahamas was unknown but that foul play was not suspected.

item.title: Francia Márquez Could Become Colombias First Black Vice President
item.description: Francia Márquez could soon be Colombia’s first Black vice president, and she has cracked open a discussion about race and class in a manner rarely seen in national politics.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Francia Márquez, a former housekeeper, is now Colombia’s leading vice-presidential candidate in a national election later this month.

item.title: One Village at a Time: The Grinding Artillery War in Ukraine
item.description: The advances by the Ukrainian army in the north have been modest, but they are emblematic of both sides’ strategy: maneuvering artillery to gain territory.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Ukrainian Bomb-Sniffing Dog Named Patron Honored by Zelensky
item.description: Patron has found more than 200 explosives, President Zelensky said. The dog has gone viral as Ukraine wages an information war.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Oleg Petrasyuk/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Patron on the job at the Gostomel airfield near Kyiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia’s Pre-Holiday Push
item.description: Plus Hong Kong’s new leader and a Taliban decree targeting women’s dress.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Evgenia Novozhenina/Reuters
item.media:description: Russians prepared for the Victory Day military parade in Moscow.

item.title: G7 Nations Pledge to Ban or Phase Out the Import of Russian Oil
item.description: With much of Europe dependent on Russian oil, the Group of 7 said the ban would take effect in a “timely and orderly fashion.”
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Thibault Camus
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France was among the G7 leaders meeting in a video-conference on Sunday.

item.title: Brazil Replenishes Stockpiles of Russian Fertilizer
item.description: Officials expected the war to trap up to 15 percent of the world’s fertilizer exports in Russia. But Brazil and other countries have found a way to get it.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.category: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tivos, a cargo ship from Russia, unloading fertilizer last month onto trucks at the Port of Santos, in São Paulo, Brazil.

item.title: Ed Koch’s Secret
item.description: He defined the role of a big-city mayor, but his personal secret affected his response to a major crisis.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times

item.title: Dozens Feared Dead After Russian Airstrike Hits School Building, Officials Say
item.description: Initial reports suggested that as many as 60 people were trapped inside the building, which officials said was being used as a shelter for civilians.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: State Emergency Services/Via Reuters
item.media:description: Emergency workers responding to a fire after a building was shelled in the village of Bilohorivka, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Hundreds of Suicidal Teens Sleep in Emergency Rooms. Every Night.
item.description: With inpatient psychiatric services in short supply, adolescents are spending days, even weeks, in hospital emergency departments awaiting the help they desperately need.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel and Annie Flanagan

item.title: Fernanda Melchor Explores the Human Capacity for Violence, and Grace
item.description: “Art must leave a wound,” said the author, one of the most celebrated in new Latin American literature.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin P. Russell
item.media:credit: Zoë Noble for The New York Times

item.title: A U.N. Agency Gave $61 Million to One Family. It Didn’t Go Well.
item.description: A little-known United Nations agency decided to make an impact by doling out loans and grant money — all to a single family. It did not go well.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United Nations Office for Project Services
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United Nations headquarters in New York. Critics of the institution say there is a culture of impunity among some top leaders, who wield huge budgets with little outside oversight.

item.title: Russian Pullback Seen Near Kharkiv, Despite Victory Day Push for Gains
item.description: Advances by Ukrainian forces in the northeast appeared to have forced Russians to move back toward the border, blowing up bridges behind them and contradicting the Kremlin narrative.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Cora Engelbrecht and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents cleaning up debris from a Russian strike in Malotaranivka, near Kramatorsk in Ukraine’s eastern Donbas region, on Saturday.

item.title: Militants Kill 11 Egyptian Troops in Sinai
item.description: The militants ambushed troops guarding a water-pumping facility, before fleeing to the desert in Northern Sinai.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Taiwan and U.S. Consider Weapons Suited to Defend Against China
item.description: The Biden administration’s push for Taiwan to order missiles and smaller arms for asymmetric warfare has gained urgency since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military vehicles parading in Taipei last year. American officials are reexamining Taiwanese military to determine whether it can fight off an invasion, as Ukrainian forces have been doing.

item.title: Northern Ireland Turns to Sinn Fein
item.description: Election results reflected the demoralization of unionist voters, the disarray of their leaders and an electorate with new priorities — much of which can be traced to Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boarded-up shops on Sandy Row in Belfast last month. Northern Ireland has particularly felt the economic repercussions of Brexit.

item.title: Taliban Impose Head-to-Toe Coverings for Women
item.description: A new decree recommends, but doesn’t require that women wear burqas, and says male relatives of those who don’t cover themselves would be punished.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Safiullah Padshah
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women wearing burqas shopping at a market in Kabul, in November.

item.title: As Tunisia’s Democratic Experiment Unravels, Economic Collapse Looms
item.description: The president is consolidating one-man rule while the economy, sapped by mismanagement, the pandemic and war in Ukraine, flails. Groups that helped avert a past crisis are largely silent.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Medina quarter of Tunis. A new constitution and several free and fair elections have failed to deliver the bread, jobs and dignity that Tunisians demanded after ousting a longtime dictator.

item.title: Two Europes Confront Each Other Over the Glory, or Shame, of War
item.description: On Monday, Vladimir Putin will mark Russia’s Victory Day by extolling the virtues of force. France’s leader, Emmanuel Macron, will honor a very different anniversary.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Natalia Kolesnikova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Planes flew over Red Square in Moscow on Wednesday in a rehearsal for the Victory Day parade.

item.title: The Friends We Keep
item.description: Our time and attention are valuable resources, and we’re in control of how — and on whom — we spend them.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Do Canada’s Auto Industry Jobs Rest on Government Support?
item.description: A former auto industry executive argues that Canada and Ontario should rethink how they subsidize carmakers.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Rebecca Cook/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced further aid to Stellantis this week.

item.title: Hear the Weird Sounds of a Black Hole Singing
item.description: As part of an effort to “sonify” the cosmos, researchers have converted the pressure waves from a black hole into an audible … something.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: NASA/CXC/SAO/K.Arcand/SYSTEM Sounds

item.title: Lviv Reopens Art Galleries ‘to Show We Are Alive’
item.description: As the Russian invasion of Ukraine grinds on, a museum director in Ukraine’s cultural capital is turning to art as a form of resistance.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Statues, furniture and other artwork remained under protective bubble wrap at Lviv’s National Gallery this week. While the gallery’s most valuable artworks will remain in storage, some of the collection items will be put back out for exhibit in the organizations galleries.

item.title: CBS Presidents George Cheeks Tests Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: The network’s leader sat between the president and first lady, all unmasked, at the event.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: George Cheeks, the president of CBS, was seated between President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, at the White House Correspondents’ Dinner last Saturday.

item.title: The U.N. Security Council Made its First Unanimous Statement on the War
item.description: More than two months into the fighting, the body was able to agree on language that got past Russia’s veto power.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: The United Nations Security Council in New York City on Thursday, during a meeting about the ongoing situation in Ukraine.

item.title: Italy Seizes Superyacht Tied to Putin
item.description: Italian police boarded the yacht, the Scheherazade, late on Friday, ending what appeared to be preparations to set sail.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Gaia Pianigiani/The New York Times
item.media:description: The superyacht Scheherazade on Wednesday in Marina di Carrara, on Italy’s northwest coast.

item.title: The Deeper Meaning of Elvis in Australia
item.description: I went to the Parkes Elvis Festival thinking I’d learn something about what America used to be. I left thinking more about Australia.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Abigail Varney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chlidren waiting for the start of the parade.

item.title: Using Weapons From the West, Ukraine Seeks to Drive Back Russian Troops
item.description: Ukrainian forces are seeking to drive back Russian invaders from two key cities in northeast Ukraine and achieve a breakthrough in what has become a grinding battle.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Cora Engelbrecht and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers greeting each other along the road on Friday near Pokrovsk, in eastern Ukraine’s Donbas region. Fighting has intensified in Donbas in advance of May 9th, Russia’s Victory Day, when Russia celebrates the Soviet Union’s victory over Nazi Germany.

item.title: Boris Johnson and His Party Suffer Setbacks in Local Voting in Britain
item.description: But the British leader appeared to have survived the storm — for now at least — as the head of the opposition Labour Party came under scrutiny for violating lockdown rules himself.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Daniel Leal
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson at a school in South Ruislip on Friday.

item.title: Sinn Fein Is Emerging As the Largest Party in Northern Ireland
item.description: Final results should be available by Saturday. Some fear it could rekindle unrest between Catholics and Protestants.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The president of Sinn Fein, Mary Lou McDonald, center right, last week in Belfast, Northern Ireland. The party’s campaign focused on issues like the cost of living, rather than Irish unity.

item.title: Belarus Sentences the Russian Law Student Who Was a Dissident’s Girlfriend to Six Years in Prison
item.description: Sofia Sapega was traveling from Greece to Lithuania with her romantic partner, Roman Protasevich, when the Belarusian air traffic control diverted their plane to Minsk, where they were both arrested.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Belta, via Reuters
item.media:description: Sofia Sapega in court in Grodno, Belarus, on Friday, in a photo distributed by state media.

item.title: Hotel Saratoga Explosion Updates: Multiple Dead in Apparent Gas Leak
item.description: A blast caused by an apparent gas leak left dozens injured and destroyed parts of a luxury hotel in Havana. Others were possibly trapped inside the rubble.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Alexandre Meneghini/Reuters
item.media:description: The aftermath of an explosion ripped through the Hotel Saratoga on Friday in central Havana. Officials said the blast was believed to have been caused by a gas leak.

item.title: Who Will Be in the Queen’s Jubilee Photo-Op?
item.description: Neither Prince Harry and his wife Meghan, nor Prince Andrew will get a place on the balcony at Buckingham Palace. It’s not even certain Queen Elizabeth, 96, will be there.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Toby Melville/Reuters
item.media:description: Workers building temporary structures around Buckingham Palace in London ahead of the Platinum Jubilee.

item.title: U.K. Police Reopen Lockdown Inquiry into Labour Leader Keir Starmer
item.description: The police are taking another look at allegations that Keir Starmer drank beer in a lawmaker’s office, potentially subjecting him to political headaches similar to those suffered by Boris Johnson.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Molly Darlington/Reuters
item.media:description: The Labour Party leader, Keir Starmer, speaking with retirees in Wakefield, northern England, on Wednesday.

item.title: How the King of Rock ’n’ Roll Still Makes Australia Sing
item.description: Elvis never played a concert “down under,” but that hasn’t stopped tens of thousands of Australians from making him their own at an annual festival.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Abigail Varney
item.media:credit: Abigail Varney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Participants in the Elvis festival’s parade posing for photos, in Parkes, Australia, last month.

item.title: Biden’s Unpopularity
item.description: Covid helps explain it.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House yesterday.

item.title: Worries About Covid Strain on Health Care Grow in the U.S.
item.description: The C.D.C. is also keeping a close eye on the nature of hospitalizations.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan and Sharon Otterman
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The number of people hospitalized in New York State is still much lower than during the winter Omicron peak in January.

item.title: In the Philippines, a Flourishing Ecosystem for Political Lies
item.description: Supporters of Ferdinand Marcos Jr. are using live video to spread misinformation on social media. Voters have become inured to the situation, researchers fear.
item.dc:creator: Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the presidential front-runner, livestreamed a recent campaign event in the Philippines.

item.title: The Ocean’s Biggest Garbage Pile Is Full of Floating Life
item.description: Researchers found that small sea creatures exist in equal number with pieces of plastic in parts of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, which could have implications for cleaning up ocean pollution.
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth

item.title: In Hong Kong Election, John Lee Is Running Uncontested
item.description: John Lee, a Beijing loyalist who oversaw the crackdown on pro-democracy protests, built his career by deepening his contacts within the mainland security services.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Kin Cheung/Associated Press
item.media:description: John Lee, the only candidate running for Hong Kong’s top job, announcing his policy manifesto during a campaign event in April. The former security secretary has spent decades in the police and security bureau.

item.title: A Psychedelic Trip to Timothy Leary’s Catalina Resort in Mexico
item.description: Most travelers descending on Zihuatanejo are unaware of the resort city’s storied past with the apostle of psychedelic drugs, and his experiments in consciousness expansion.
item.dc:creator: Nina Burleigh
item.media:credit: Adrian Wilson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of Zihuatanejo, Mexico, from the sunset bar at the Hotel Catalina Beach Resort. The hotel was the setting of an ecstatic 1960s retreat organized by Timothy Leary, an apostle of psychedelic drugs.

item.title: Sinn Fein Expected to Win Northern Ireland Election
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Sinn Fein election poster next to a mural in favor of a united Ireland on Falls Road, a Catholic stronghold in Belfast.

item.title: What were people voting for?
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street in Belfast, Northern Ireland, where voters selected representatives not for local councils but for their legislature.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Ukrainian forces regain ground from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Surveying the damage after attacks in the city of Kramatorsk, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Putin’s Forces Battle in East Ukraine to Feed His Hunger for a Victory
item.description: The fighting has intensified ahead of Russia’s May 9 Victory Day holiday commemorating the Soviet Union’s triumph over Nazi Germany.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military doctor helping to transport a wounded soldier from a field hospital yesterday.

item.title: Pope Approved Secret Deal to Free Abducted Nun, Cardinal Says
item.description: A formerly top-ranking cardinal testified Thursday that the pope said he could spend up to one million euros to secure the release of a nun kidnapped by Islamic militants.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandra Tarantino/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pope Francis, who has been suffering knee strain, arrives in a wheelchair to attend an audience with nuns and religious superiors in the Paul VI Hall at The Vatican on Thursday.

item.title: Jill Biden Embarks on Trip to Eastern Europe to Visit Ukrainian Refugees
item.description: The first lady is also scheduled to tour the Slovakian border with Ukraine, becoming the latest high-profile Biden administration official to come close to the conflict zone.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: The first lady, Jill Biden, will travel to Eastern Europe this weekend to meet with Ukrainian refugees, American troops and Romania’s first lady.

item.title: North Carolina state employees will receive paid time off to get booster shots, the governor said.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Veasey Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pharmacist administering a Covid-19 booster shot on Thursday in Durham, N.C.
